./.title: Introduction
./.summary:
Hi! Welcome to the Angular 2 Handbook! This book will get you
started on the path to becoming an Angular 2 expert .
./.body:
Angular 2 Handbook
Hi! Welcome to the Angular 2 Handbook! This book will get you
started on the path to becoming an Angular 2 expert .
The Angular 2 Cheatsheet
This is a great reference to have open to while your learning all
the new syntax:
https://angular.io/cheatsheet
Organization
Each chapter is broken into:

TL;DR - A summary of chapter
Chapter Topics - Paragraphs of text and code about the topics
Show me the Code - The code for quick reference later
What's that Sytax? - Explanation of JavaScript and/or TypeScript
syntax that might be new

built-in-directives/.title: 05. Built-in Directives
built-in-directives/.summary:
In Angular 1, it was confusing when you should use {{}} inside of 
attributes. Angular 2 should consistently always use [] for 
input/setting values and () for output/getting values.

events-and-refs/.title: 03. Events and Refs
events-and-refs/.summary:
Events are part of every application. Your user is going to click, type,
resize, etc, etc, so you'd better know how to accomodate them ! Events are handled by wrapping the event name inside of (). So if you
want to handle a click on a button, you type:

first-component/.title: 02. First Component
first-component/.body:
First Component
TL;DR
You make a component with a @Component decorator and a class. The
@Component requires a selector and a template, then you include
the component in a parent Component using directives: [].
Components
Components are the backbone of Angular 2. You will be writing a lot*
of components, so you'll get accustomed to the new syntax quickly .
A Component is the combination of a class and a @Component 
decorator. 
class
The class is a typical JavaScript class whose purpose is to support
the template of the component. For example, you'll handle events from
the template inside your class.
@Component
The @Component is a Decorator that maps the selector and the 
template to the class. 
selector
Every @Component needs a selector
so that it knows where it is declared in parent templates.
template
Every @Component also needs a template that will be rendered
wherever the component is included.
 Ambiguity Alert!
"Component" is used interchangably to describe the @Component 
decorator as well as the combination of the decorator and the class.
The class is often called a controller. That's mostly a due to the
naming conventions of Angular 1, but the name suits it fine.
A @Component is a @Directive with a template, so you include
your component class in the parents' directives:[] array.
 I'm so confused... 
Relax  .  All components look alike. In fact, the patterns will 
become very easy to read when you see many of them together. After 
you've created your third or fourth component, you'll be used to the 
patterns (you might even be copy and pasting from others components) 
enough that you won't really care about the syntax anymore.
Show Me the Code

src/components/first.component.ts

import {Component} from 'angular2/core';

@Component({
    selector: 'first',
    template: `
            I have a message for you: 
        `
})
export class First{
    message = "Hi!";
}


src/app.ts

import {Component} from 'angular2/core';
import {First} from './components/first.component';

@Component({
    selector: 'app',
    directives:[First],
    template: `
        <first></first>
    `
})
export class App{
}

 Gotchas
If you have a blank page, check these first:

You included your component in the directives:[] Array
Your selector:'' name matches the <selector> in the template

What's That Syntax?
``  Multiline Strings
The backticks are used for multiline strings which makes 
them perfect for HMTL templates:
var s = `I am a string`;

var template = `
    <div>I am also a string!</div>
`;

hello-world/.title: 01. Hello World
hello-world/.summary:
You bootstrap an App Component to startup your app in the <app>
tag of your HTML.

http/.title: 08. Loading Data with Http
http/.summary:
The http service is included in the angular2/http package. You
can actually use whatever http services you'd like with Angular 2,
http is simply a convenience. To use the http service, you'll need to include the HTTP_PROVIDERS
either in the same Component's providers:[] or in a parent 
Component'...

injecting-services/.title: 07. Injecting Services

new-project/.title: 00. New Project
new-project/.summary:
The angular-cli will help you get your Angular 2 project up and 
running quickly. https://github.com/angular/angular-cli You can follow the instructions there to get it installed.
new-project/.body:
Creating a New Project From Scratch
The Angular CLI
The angular-cli will help you get your Angular 2 project up and 
running quickly.
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli
You can follow the instructions there to get it installed.
The Angular Seed Project
If you prefer to use WebPack or have more control, there's also 
https://github.com/angular/angular2-seed.
Both approaches work great and can generate a build for you, so I'll 
leave it up to your preference on how you want to manage your project.

ngFor/.title: 06. Repeating Elements with ngFor
